greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest number having exactly n divisors of the form 8*k + 5.
comment: Smallest index of n in A188171.

a(n) exists for all n, since 5*3^(2n-2) has exactly n divisors of the form 8*k + 1, namely 5*3^0, 5*3^2, ..., 5*3^(2n-2). This actually gives an upper bound (which is too far from reality when n is large) for a(n).
link: Bert Dobbelaere, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..200
formula: a(2n) <= 3^(n-1) * 455, since 3^(n-1) * 455 has exactly 2n divisors congruent to 5 modulo 8: 3^0 * 5, 3^2 * 5, ..., 3^b * 5, 3^1 * 7, 3^3 * 7, ..., 3^a * 7, 3^0 * 13, 3^2 * 13, ..., 3^b * 13, 3^1 * 455, 3^3 * 455, ... 3^a * 455, where a is the largest odd number <= n-1 and b is the largest even number <= n-1.
example: a(4) = 585 since it is the smallest number with exactly 4 divisors congruent to 5 modulo 8, namely 5, 13, 45 and 585.
xref: Smallest number having exactly n divisors of the form 8*k + i: A343104 (i=1), A343105 (i=3), this sequence (i=5), A188226 (i=7).
results.author: _Jianing Song_, Apr 05 2021
